text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- The ruling Bulgarian Socialist Party said it had accepted in principle the opposition's idea of holding early parliamentary elections in the context of a national programme to end the current crisis in the country. @

-- Bulgaria's Finance Ministry has approached the State Fund for Reconstruction and Development (SFRD) which collects external loans, to extend $160 million to the budget to service payments on Bulgaria's foreign debt due in January, a SRDF senior top official said.

-- Bulgaria's main opposition Union of Democratic Forces rejected the proposal of the ruling socialist party (BSP) to discuss ways out of the political crisis, saying there was no firm commitment on the part of BSP to hold early parliamentary elections by the year's end, UDF leader Ivan Kostov said. @

-- Former economic advisor to the outgoing Prime Minister Zhan Videnov Ivan Angelov demanded an immediate investigation into the incomes of all ministers, politicians and deputies of the past seven years in a bid to fight corruption in the Bulgaria.
-- Bulgaria's state Agriculture fund said it would continue to extend credits to grain producers at half the central interest rate, now set at 180 percent annually.
-- Bulgaria's biggest oil refinery Neftohim posted some 80 billion lev loss in 1996, Balkan news agency reported.
-- Bulgaria's Sunny Beach Black Sea resort posted one billion lev net profit in 1996, a Sunny Beach top official said.

-- Bulgaria's biggest Confederation of Independent Trade Unions and the Confederation of Labour Podkrepa said that they would join the national political strike set for Wednesday by the opposition with calls for early parliamentary elections.
-- Bulgaria's police said it had seized seven mobile phones tuned to police frequency belonging to an Eurovision TV team in Sofia covering current social unrest.

-- Central heating in Sofia and another nine large Bulgarian cities is expected to be switched off because the state gas monopolist Bulgargas had curtailed gas deliveries to heating stations over unpaid debts, a Bulgargas official said. -- Sofia Newsroom, (++359-2) 981 8569
